metadata.case_name: State of Assam & Ors. v. Ajit Kumar Sharma

facts.text: Shri Ajit Kumar Sharma is a teacher in Handique Girls College at Gauhati, a private college teaching up to B.A. standard, affiliated to Gauhati University under Gauhati University Act No. 16 of 1947.
College managed by Governing Body according to Statute for management of private colleges framed by Gauhati University under s. 21(g) of the Act.

Under s. 23(h) of the Act, Executive Council may frame Ordinances for emoluments and conditions of service of teachers including in private colleges; University framed leave rules for private colleges, binding on Governing Bodies, adopted by College Governing Body in July 1956.
Leave rules do not permit Governing Body to compel teacher to take leave without pay.

College receives grant-in-aid from State of Assam; conditions for grant-in-aid do not provide for withdrawal if college fails to put teacher seeking election on compulsory leave without pay from filing of nomination till end of next academic session or term.
Respondent applied for leave with pay from January 2, 1962 to March 5, 1962 to contest Parliament seat; granted by Governing Body resolution No. 1 dated March 9, 1962.
Respondent defeated in election, applied to rejoin from March 6, 1962; permitted by Governing Body resolution No. 2 dated March 9, 1962.

Director of Public Instruction, Assam wrote to Principal/Secretary on March 20, 1962, disapproving resolution permitting rejoining, citing contravention of r. 7 of Rules regarding Conduct and Discipline of Employees of Aided Educational Institutions; Rules framed in 1960 after consultation with University and Assam College Teachers Association.

Governing Body reconsidered and passed resolution on April 4, 1962: resolution of March 9 permitting rejoining not to be given effect; respondent granted compulsory leave without pay till end of academic session per Rules.
Principal informed respondent by letter dated April 5, 1962 of compulsory leave without pay.
Respondent filed writ petition in Assam High Court (Civil Rule No. 221 of 1962); High Court judgment dated September 25, 1962.

In February 1959, State decided additional grant-in-aid to private colleges for UGC pay scales; on condition colleges abide by rules on service conditions, framed after consultation with University, Teachers Association, Governing Bodies.
College Governing Body resolved on August 6, 1960 agreeing to proposed rules.
Rules notified March 9, 1961, published March 29, 1961.
Rule 7: Employee seeking election to Legislative Body etc. on compulsory leave without pay from filing nomination till end of next academic session or term; lien not exceeding 5 years.
Governing Body consulted and accepted Rules; teachers represented; Government gave revised grants post-acceptance.
Additional Director letter March 19, 1962 threatened no funds for salaries if contravention of r.7.
Assam Act 11 of 1961 added proviso to s.21(g) empowering Government to make rules for aided colleges in consultation with University.
High Court held Rules no statutory force, but issued mandamus to Director and direction to Governing Body not to give effect to Director's letter.
State/Director granted special leave by Supreme Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether the High Court was right in issuing a writ of mandamus to the State through the Director directing it not to give effect to the letter of March 20, 1962, given that the Rules have no statutory force.
Whether Rules have statutory force under proviso to s.21(g) of Gauhati University Act as amended.
Whether writ or direction can issue to Governing Body of private college.

petitioner_arguments.text: Rules referred by Director have no statutory force; entitled to leave under University rules accepted by College; Rules do not affect Governing Body powers.
Director has no authority to interfere with Governing Body resolutions; no approval needed.
University leave rules do not empower compulsory leave without pay against teacher's will; April 4 resolution ineffective; Governing Body should not act on illegal direction.
Governing Body acted on threat in Additional Director's letter March 19; Director no right to threaten.
Even if no statutory force, High Court should not issue writ against administrative instructions; contractual, not enforceable by writ.

respondent_arguments.text: Rules binding on College and teachers as framed after consultation with University, Teachers Association, Governing Bodies; College accepted to get revised grants.
Rules have statutory force via amendment Assam Act 11 of 1961 proviso to s.21(g).
Teachers including respondent accepted benefits under grant-in-aid scheme bound by Rules; estopped from challenging.
Governing Body resolution April 4 not due to threat.
Even if no statutory force, mere executive instructions for grant-in-aid; no writ against State for administrative instructions; matter between Government and College.
No right on teachers from such instructions; cannot seek enforcement or non-enforcement via writ.

court_reasoning.text: High Court erred in granting mandamus against State/Director once Rules found to have no statutory force; they are mere executive instructions conditioning grant-in-aid.
court_reasoning.key_observation: State can prescribe grant conditions by executive instructions; private college accepts or rejects; teachers have no rights thereunder enforceable by writ.

court_reasoning.text: Rules framed to implement UGC pay recommendations via grants; college accepted; if not followed, State can withhold grant; matter between State and college.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Teachers cannot insist on enforcement/non-enforcement; no vested right from administrative instructions.

court_reasoning.text: References Raman and Raman v. State of Madras: executive instructions do not confer rights enforceable as law.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Rules partake of administrative character; no basis for writ under Art. 226.

court_reasoning.text: No interference with High Court order against Governing Body as no appeal by it; but not approved.

holdings.text: High Court erred in issuing writ/mandamus against State through Director; set aside that part.
Rules are mere administrative instructions for grant-in-aid; confer no rights on teachers for writ petition under Art. 226.
No opinion expressed approving writ against Governing Body.

precedents_cited.case_name: Raman and Raman v. The State of Madras
precedents_cited.relevance: Executive instructions/orders do not have status of law conferring rights; administrative in character.

statutes_cited.name: Gauhati University Act, No. 16 of 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for University statutes/ordinances on college management and teacher service conditions; proviso added by Assam Act 11 of 1961 for government rules on aided colleges.

statutes_cited.name: Assam Act 11 of 1961
statutes_cited.relevance: Empowers Government to make rules for aided colleges in consultation with University.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: High Court power to issue writs/directions; not for enforcing administrative instructions lacking statutory force.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; High Court order issuing mandamus/direction against State/Director set aside; no interference with order against Governing Body as no appeal by it. State stated it would not enforce r.7 against respondent.

key_quotes.text: "The Rules being mere administrative instructions are matters between private colleges and the Government in the matter of grant-in-aid to such colleges, and no teacher of a college has any right under the Rules to ask either for their enforcement or for their non-enforcement."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on no locus for teachers to challenge grant conditions via writ.

key_quotes.text: "What grants the State should make to private educational institutions and upon what terms are matters for the State to decide."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Affirms executive discretion in grant conditions.

key_quotes.text: "Such mere administrative instructions even though called rules are only a matter between the Governing Body and the State through the Director and cannot in our opinion form the basis of a petition for writ under Art. 226 by a teacher."
key_quotes.speaker: court
